The roles of metal-promoter interface on liquid phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde over Ir-MoOx/BN catalysts Cen Tang Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Writing - original draft a Fangru Zhou Investigation a Yang Wen Investigation a Yumeng Xu Investigation Formal analysis a Aiping Jia Investigation a Mengfei Luo Conceptualization Methodology Resources a b Jiqing Lu Conceptualization Methodology Resources Supervision Writing - review & editing a b * a College of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua, 321004, China College of Chemistry and Life Sciences Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China College of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, China b Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials Institute of Physical Chemistry China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry ⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua, 321004, China. College of Chemistry and Life Sciences Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China Graphical abstract A series of MoOx-promoted Ir/BN catalysts were tested for liquid phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde. The MoOx-promotion could significantly improve the reactivity up to 5-fold. Such improvement was mainly due to the formation of Ir-MoOx interfacial sites in the promoted catalyst, which accelerated the adsorption and activation of crotonaldehyde molecule as evidenced by a much lower activation energy (18.9 kJ mol−1 on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN versus 38.4 kJ mol−1 on the 3Ir/BN). The kinetic results revealed negative reaction order of crotonaldehyde (up to -1.1) and high reaction order of H2 (up to 2.2), indicating the high coverage of crotonaldehyde on the catalyst surface suppressed the adsorption of H2 due to its low solubility in the liquid phase. Therefore, the adsorption and activation of H2 on the catalyst might be the rate determining step. However, the preferred adsorption of crotonaldehyde on the Ir-MoOx interface alleviated the suppression of H2 adsorption, which was another reason for the higher activity. Keywords Selective hydrogenation α, β - Unsaturated aldehyde Adsorption and activation Kinetics Reaction mechanism 1 Introduction The selective hydrogenation of, α, β - unsaturated aldehydes to their corresponding unsaturated alcohols is of great importance in the synthesis of fine chemicals such as fragrances, agrochemicals and pharmaceuticals [1,2]. The hydrogenation of α, β - unsaturated aldehydes over heterogeneous catalysts employing H2 as the reducing agent is very appealing because of its high atomic efficiency. Yet, it is not an easy task to obtain high selectivity to the desired unsaturated alcohol as the hydrogenation tends to occur on the CC bond in the aldehyde molecule, which is more thermodynamically favorable than that on the CO bond by about 35 kJ mol−1 [3–5]. Efforts have been made to improve the catalytic performance for the reaction, particularly the selectivity. It is well recognized that the distributions of the products are closely related to the adsorption geometries of the unsaturated aldehyde molecules on the catalyst surface, which consequently affects the hydrogenation behaviors. Since the preferred adsorption of CO bond is beneficial to the formation of unsaturated alcohol while the adsorption of CC bond results in the formation of saturated aldehyde, high selectivity to the unsaturated alcohol could be achieved if the CO bond predominantly adsorbs on the catalyst surface. Engineering of the catalyst surface is a promising strategy to adjust the adsorption modes of the unsaturated aldehyde. One approach is the use of reducible supports that present the strong metal support interaction (SMSI) effect. Oxides such as TiO2 [6] or CeO2 [7] are good supports for the noble metals (e.g. Ir and Pt) to promote the selectivity to the hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde. For example, it was reported that the Ir/TiO2 catalysts gave high selectivity to crotyl alcohol in the hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde due to the formation of di-σCO mode adsorption of CO bond at Ir-TiO2 interface [8]. Such strategy of the generation of interfacial sites could be extended to metal-promoter [9–14] and metal-metal alloy [15–17] systems. Among the employed noble metals, iridium (Ir) appears to be more selective than other metals (e.g. Pt and Au) for α, β - unsaturated aldehyde, especially for those small molecules such as crotonaldehyde [10,18–22], due to its larger d-band width resulting enhanced adsorption of CO bond and suppressed adsorption of CC bond [23,24]. It was reported that the Ir/SiO2 catalyst [22] could give a selectivity of 77 % to crotyl alcohol in hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde, while on the Pt/SiO2 [25] and Pd/NRGO [26] catalysts the dominant product is butanal. Moreover, by addition of the second mental such as MoOx, WOx, NbOx, FeOx and ReOx could greatly enhanced the performance (both activity and selectivity) of the Ir catalysts for hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde [27], due to the generation metal-promoter interface which are beneficial for the reaction [18,27–29]. For example, the decoration of Ir by MoOx on TUD-1 catalyst [29] resulted in the adsorption of CO bond preferentially on the MoOx, which could react with the dissociated H species on Ir to form crotyl alcohol. It is worth mentioning that although noble metals are the main catalysts for the reaction, it was recently reported that non-noble metal such as Co shows high performance in the selective hydrogenation of various unsaturated aldehydes [30]. Kinetic study is helpful to understand the underlying reaction mechanism. For gas phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde, it was reported that the promoted activity on the Ir-FeOx/BN catalyst was related to the enhanced the adsorption of crotonaldehyde molecules at Ir-FeOx interface [12]. Regarding the liquid phase reaction, works performed in this area mainly addressed selectivity issues and few quantitative kinetic data were reported. Reyes et al. [31] found near negative second - order dependence on citral concentration and first - order dependence on hydrogen pressure in liquid-phase hydrogenation of citral over Ir/TiO2 catalysts, which revealed competitive adsorption between citral and hydrogen and the hydrogen adsorption on the active sites was the rate-limiting step. Koo-amornpattana and Winterbottom [32] reported the kinetic of cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation on Pt- and Pt-alloy catalysts and the authors found that the reaction was zero - order in cinnamaldehyde concentration and first - order in hydrogen partial pressure, which indicated that the reaction was significantly transport controlled and gas absorption resistance was more significant than liquid - solid mass transport. Also, liquid - phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde over Au/Mg2AlO catalysts gave a reaction order of 1.8 in respect to H2 partial pressure [33]. A kinetic approach to a better mechanistic understanding of liquid phase hydrogenation reactions has already proven to be valuable [34,35]. Therefore, in the current work, we prepared a series of MoOx - promoted Ir/BN catalysts and tested them for liquid phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde. The performance of the promoted catalyst was compared with that of the bare Ir/BN, and the roles of MoOx promotion were clarified by spectroscopic characterizations and kinetic investigation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supported Ir/BN catalyst was prepared by impregnating commercial hexagonal BN (h-BN, Aladdin, 99.9 %, SBET = 18.5 m2 g−1) with an aqueous solution of H2IrCl6 (Macklin, Ir content of 35 wt.% in HCl) at room temperature. The suspension was continuously stirred for 4 h (rpm = 450). After solvent evaporation by water bath at 90 °C and drying at 80 °C overnight, the solid was heated to 500 °C at a ramp of 5 °C min−1 and kept for 4 h in static air to obtain the catalyst. The MoOx promoted Ir/BN catalysts were also prepared using an impregnation method. In detail, a certain amount of calcined Ir/BN powder was added in an aqueous solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24 · 4H2O (Aladdin, 100 %) for 4 h at room temperature, followed by drying at 80 °C overnight and calcination at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain the final catalyst. The nominal contents of Ir in all catalysts were 3 wt.%. The catalysts were denoted as nMo-3Ir/BN, with n referring to the weight percentage of Mo in the catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The specific surface areas of the catalysts were measured by N2 adsorption at 77 K on a Quantachrome Nova 4000e surface area analyzer. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE powder X-ray diffractometer using Cu Ka radiation, which was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The patterns were collected in a 2θ range from 10 to 90°, with a scanning step of 0.02° s−1. Before the measurements, the samples were pre-reduced in a H2 flow (99.99 %, 26 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was performed on a JEM-2100 F microscopy operated at 200 kV. Before the measurements, the catalysts were pre-reduced in a H2 flow (99.999 %, 26 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h. The reducibility of the catalyst was measured by hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment on a MicrotracBEL BELCAT II automatic chemisorption analyzer. 50 mg of the catalyst was loaded in a quartz tubular reactor, and was heated to 300 °C in a pure O2 flow (30 mL min−1) and then kept at 300 °C for 0.5 h, followed by Ar purge (30 mL min−1) for 0.5 h to remove the gaseous or physically adsorbed O2. After the sample was cooled down to room temperature, it was heated to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 in a 5 % H2 + 95 % Ar mixture (30 mL min−1). The signal was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), and the H2 consumption was calibrated by the reduction of CuO powder with a known amount. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the catalysts were recorded on an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al anode Ka radiation (1486.6 eV), and the charging effects were corrected by setting the C1s binding energy of the adventitious carbon to 284.8 eV. Prior to the measurement, the sample was reduced in a pretreatment chamber in high purity hydrogen (> 99.99 %, 26 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h, and was cooled down to room temperature. Then the sample was directly transferred to analysis chamber without being exposed to the environment. The obtained XPS data were fitted by a XPS peak 4.1 software. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra of CO chemisorption on the samples were recorded using a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector and a PIKE DRIFT accessory. Prior to the measurement, the sample was in situ reduced in a H2 flow (99.99 %, 26 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h and purged by a flow of N2 (30 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h. The sample was cooled down to 30 °C and the backgrounds were collected at temperature intervals (30–100 °C). After the sample was exposed to a 1 % CO in N2 (20 mL min−1) for 15 min and purged by N2 purge for another 1 h, it was heated from 30 to 100 °C at a ramp of 10 °C min−1, and the spectra were recorded with subtracted the background at the corresponding temperature. In all cases the spectra were taken with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and cumulative 64 scans. In situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of crotonaldehyde adsorption and in - situ reaction was performed on the same FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50). The sample with a weight of about 15–20 mg was pressed into a 13 mm self-supported wafer and placed into a quartz in situ IR cell. The catalyst was reduced at 300 °C under a H2 flow (99.99 %, 26 mL min−1) for 1 h and purged with a N2 flow for another 1 h (to remove the adsorbed H2 on the catalyst surface) then cooled to 80 °C, and the background was collected at certain temperature points. Crotonaldehyde vapor was introduced to the sample for 10 min by passing the N2 flow through a saturated vapor generator containing liquid crotonaldehyde maintained at 0 °C. After that the sample was purged by N2 for another 1 h in order to remove the gaseous and physisorbed crotonaldehyde and then the spectrum was recorded. Then the catalyst was heated from 80 to 180 °C at a ramp of 5 °C min−1 in the N2 flow to monitor the desorption behaviors of crotonaldehyde. For the in-situ reaction, after the sample was reduced and cooled down to 30 °C, during which the backgrounds with different temperature points were collected. Afterwards, the crotonaldehyde vapor was introduced to the sample with a H2 flow (20 mL min−1). Then it was purged with a N2 flow for 3 h, the gas was switched to H2 (26 mL min−1) and the sample was heated from 30 to 80 °C at a ramp of 2 °C min−1, and the spectra were collected with corresponding backgrounds at different temperatures. 2.3 Catalytic reaction and kinetic study The liquid phase crotonaldehyde hydrogenation was performed in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave (custom-designed, Keli Chem ical Equipment Co., China). Prior to the experiment, 100 mg of the catalyst was pretreated in a specially designed quartz tube under H2 (99.999 %, 26 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h. 14.5 mL of isopropanol was injected to the tube under H2 flow and the catalyst was immersed by the solvent until cooled down to room temperature. Then the suspension was immediately transferred into the autoclave without exposure to air and mixed with crotonaldehyde (6.0 mmol), followed by H2 recharge and vent 11 times to remove the air in the autoclave. The reaction began when the temperature reached 80 °C, while constant hydrogen (99.999 %, kept at 0.6 MPa) gas was introduced to the reaction under stirring at 80 °C (800 rpm). The reaction was stopped after 3 h and the reaction products and reactant were analyzed on line using a gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a DB-Wax capillary column (30 m ×0.25 mm ×0.25 μm). The kinetic study was performed on two representative catalysts (3Ir/BN and 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN) on the same reactor as mentioned above. The effect of crotonaldehyde concentration was studied in the concentration range from 2.4 to 6.0 mmol, while the effect of hydrogen partial pressure was studied in the range from 0.4 to 1 MPa. In all cases, the conversion levels were controlled below 15 % to ensure differential mode reactions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 General characterizations The catalysts have similar surface areas (22.8–26.6 m2 g−1, Table 1 ). The pre-reduced catalysts give typical diffractions of hexagonal BN (h-BN, JCPDS No. 34-0421) and metallic Ir (JCPDS No. 46-1044), as shown in Fig. 1 . However, no distinct diffractions of Mo species could be observed, indicating the MoOx species are highly dispersed on the 3Ir/BN surface. The morphological features of the catalysts were investigated by HRTEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . Metallic Ir species are confirmed in the pre-reduced 3Ir/BN, 0.1Mo-3Ir/BN and 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalysts, with the measurement of lattice fringes featuring (111) plane (d Ir (111) =0.225 nm). For the MoOx - containing catalysts, the presence of MoOx is identified by the lattice fringe measurements (e.g. MoO3 (220) =0.233 nm in Fig. 2b and MoO2 (002) =0.211 nm in Fig. 2c). Moreover, the Ir-MoOx interaction is clearly observed in the 0.1Mo-3Ir/BN and 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalysts, as evidenced by the contacted Ir and MoOx particles (Fig. 2b - c). Such interaction could be due to electrostatic interaction between the Irδ + and the Mo7O24 6− during the preparation process, in which Mo species will selectively deposit on Ir particle to form the Ir-Mo interface [29]. The mean Ir particle sizes of the catalysts are ca. 2–3 nm, which are smaller than those on SiO2 (e.g. 4–5 nm [20,28,36]). The smaller Ir particle size on the BN support is related to the strong interaction between the metal atoms and defect sites in h-BN (e.g. boron vacancy and nitrogen edge) [37]. Fig. 3 shows the H2-TPR profiles of different catalysts. The 3Mo/BN catalyst gives a reduction peak centered at 560 °C due to the reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 [38], while the 3Ir/BN catalyst gives a reduction peak centered at 230 °C due to the reduction of IrOx species. For the MoOx-promoted catalysts, two reduction peaks are observed. The peak centered at 230–290 °C could be assigned to the reduction of IrOx and the peak centered at ca. 450 °C could be assigned to the reduction of MoOx. It is found that the low - temperature reduction peak of the IrOx (230 °C) slightly shifts to higher temperature (245–290 °C) while the high-temperature reduction peak of the MoOx (560 °C) slightly shifts to lower temperature (460 - 450 °C) with increasing Mo content in the catalyst. This observation implies that the IrOx-MoOx interaction lead to more difficult reduction of IrOx species but easier reduction of MoOx species due to the typical spillover effect. Fig. 4 shows the XPS spectra of the Ir and Mo species in the pre-reduced catalysts. The Ir 4f 7/2 spectra (Fig. 4a) could be resolved to two components at BEs of 61.2–61.4 and 62.3–62.6 eV, assigning to metallic Ir0 and cationic Irδ + species, respectively [39]. It is found that the BEs of the Ir species slightly shift to higher values by 0.1 - 0.3 eV after the MoOx - promotion, indicating charge transfer from Ir to MoOx. Such charge transfer also implies stronger Ir-MoOx interaction, which is in agreement with the H2-TPR results (Fig. 3). Similar observation was also found in the Ir-FeOx/BN catalyst [12]. For the Mo 3d spectra (Fig. 4b), the catalyst with low Mo content (e.g. 0.1Mo-3Ir/BN) contains mostly Mo4+ although the signals are quite weak, but Mo6+ species become predominant when the Mo content is higher in the catalyst (e.g. 3Mo-3Ir/BN). Therefore, this observation suggests that the Ir-MoOx interaction facilitates the reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 due to the spillover effect, however, high Mo content leads to the formation of isolated MoO3 entities, which are not easy to be reduced. Such spillover effect is also confirmed by the Mo 3d XPS spectra of the 1Mo/BN reference sample (Fig. S1). It is clearly that both fresh and the pre-reduced 1Mo/BN sample contain only Mo6+ species, suggesting that the bare MoO3 species are difficult to be reduced. Such comparison of the Mo 3d XPS spectra again highlights the Ir-MoOx interaction. In situ CO-DRIFTS experiments were conducted to further probe the electronic properties of the Ir species in the pre-reduFced catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5 , The 3Ir/BN catalyst shows overlapped bands centered at 2049 and 2079 cm−1, assigning to linear adsorbed CO on metallic Ir [40–42]. The addition of MoOx in the catalyst results in a systematic red shift of these bands, which can not be explained by the typical charge enrichment of the Ir species as the XPS results (Fig. 4a) clearly suggest the opposite. Instead, the red shift might be due to the changes of the Ir particles. As the HRTEM images of the catalysts (Fig. 2) reveal that the Ir particle sizes in the Mo-promoted catalysts are slightly smaller than that in the un-promoted one, which results in higher surface electron density on the smaller metal particles and consequently lower wave number of the CO band [43]. On the other hand, in the MoOx-promoted catalysts the surface Ir atoms are isolated by the MoOx entities via Ir-MoOx interaction, which weakens the interactions between the adsorbed CO molecules and thus results in a red shift [6]. Similar observation was also reported in MoOx-promoted Ir/TUD-1 [29] and NbOx-promoted Ir/SiO2 [44] catalysts. Also, the band intensity gradually declines with increasing Mo content in the catalyst, which qualitatively suggests less exposed Ir surface atoms by MoOx coverage. Such MoOx-modification of Ir species becomes more significant on the 1Mo-3Ir/BN catalyst as it shows no observable CO band, implying the surface Ir atoms are dominantly covered by the MoOx species. Regarding the CO desorption behavior on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN at elevated temperatures (Fig. 5b), the band intensity continuously declines and the band almost disappears at 100 °C. Meanwhile, a slight red shift is observed with increasing temperature, due to the decrease in the coverage of the CO species as observed on metallic Ir species [45]. 3.2 Catalytic performances of liquid- phase crotonaldehyde hydrogenation Fig. 6 a shows the results of liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde over the catalysts. Under reaction conditions of 80 °C, H2 pressure of 0.6 MPa and reaction time of 3 h, the crotonaldehyde conversions on the catalysts follow a volcano-type trend. The 3Ir/BN catalyst gives a quite low conversion of 16.4 %, and the conversion reaches a maximum (80.4 %) at the Mo content of 0.3 wt.% (0.3Mo-Ir/BN). However, the conversion declines with increasing Mo content in the catalyst. Regarding the product selectivity, the 3Ir/BN catalyst give a considerable selectivity to the desired crotyl alcohol (CROL, 76.6 %), and the main by-products are butanal (BUAL), 1-butanol (BUOL) and others such as 2,4,6-octatrienal. The addition of small amount of Mo improves the selectivity up to ca. 88 %, and it seems that this high selectivity is barely influenced by the Mo content in the catalyst. Therefore, the formation rate of crotyl alcohol is improved by 5-fold on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN (39.4 × 10−7 mol g-1 s-1) compared with that on the 3Ir/BN (7.0 × 10−7 mol g-1 s-1), as shown in Table 1. Moreover, the catalysts are quite stable during the recycling test. As shown in Fig. 6b, the representative 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalyst does not show obvious loss of activity and selectivity during 5 cycles. To further evaluate the intrinsic activities of the two catalysts, turnover frequencies (TOF) of crotyl alcohol formation based on Ir dispersions were calculated and summarized in Table 1. The 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalyst gives a TOF of (190.2 h-1), which is four times higher than that on the 3Ir/BN (47.1 h-1). Our results are also among the best results reported in literature (Table S1). Since the isopropanol was used as the solvent, there could be possible involvement of the hydrogen species from the isopropanol molecules as recently reported by Ye et al. [46] via a catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) process. However, in our case, we did not detect the presence of acetone in the products. Therefore we believe that the CTH process may not exist in the current case due to different catalyst systems. 3.3 FTIR investigation on crotonaldehyde adsorption and in situ reaction In order to investigate the adsorption properties and reaction behaviors of crotonaldehyde, in situ FTIR spectroscopic study was conducted on some representative catalysts. We focus on the vibrations of CO and CC bonds, which are in 1500 - 1800 cm−1 region (Fig. 7 a). Gaseous crotonaldehyde gives two bands at 1712 and 1724 cm−1 due to v(CO), and a weak band at 1650 cm−1 due to v(CC). The adsorption of crotonaldehyde on the catalysts result in new bands at 1684, 1676 and 1643 cm-1 (Fig. S2). The bands at 1684 and 1676 cm−1 are assigned to v(CO) in a πCO mode and v(CO) in a di-σCO mode [6], respectively, while the band at 1643 cm−1 is assigned to v(CC) in a πCC mode [43]. These results indicate that crotonaldehyde molecules dominantly adsorb on the catalysts via carbonyl group. Morever, the bands gradually decline in intensity when the catalysts are purged by N2 at elevated temperatures (from 353 to 423 K). The changes in the band area in the range 1550 - 1750 cm−1 on the three catalysts were plotted as a function of temperature versus area percent of the corresponding band at 353 K (Fig. 7b). The band area on 0.3Mo/BN and 3Ir/BN decreased more rapidly (a larger negative slope) in comparison to that on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN. Considering the presence of Ir-MoOx interface in the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalyst, it could be concluded that the adsorption strength of crotonaldehyde molecules adsorbed on the interfacial sites are stronger than those on Ir and MoOx sites. Similar observation was also reported on Ir-ReOx/SiO2 catalyst by Tamura et al. [27]. The changes of v(CO) and v(CC) under reacton conditions (crotonaldehyde + H2) were also investigated by in situ FTIR spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 7c. For the 3Ir/BN catalyst, the intensities of the v(CO) bands at 1676 and 1684 cm−1 decreases slowly with increasing temperature, but remains substantial at 80 °C. In contrast, the desorption rate of these bands are much faster on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN and 3Mo-3Ir/BN catalysts, as shown in Fig. 7d. It thus suggests that the reaction rates on the MoOx-promoted catalysts are higher than that on the bare 3Ir/BN, which is in agreement with the overall activity (Fig. 6). Note that the disappearance of these bands at elevated temperatures is not due to the desorption of crotonaldehyde from the catalyst surface, as it is clear that substantial bands are observed at 80 °C when the catalyst is exposed to crotonaldehyde (Fig. 7a). Also, diminish of the v(CO) bands is accompanied by the emergence of bands at 2879, 2924, 2940, 2963, 3027 and 3320 cm−1 (Fig. S3). The first five bands are assigned to aliphatic or olefinic v(CH) bands [18], and the band at 3320 cm−1 is assigned to surface hydroxyl group. The observation of these bands implies unsaturated alcohol is formed on the catalyst surface. These findings imply that on the MoOx-promoted 3Ir/BN catalysts the hydrogenation of CO bond is fast and dominant, although hydrogenation of CC bond also occurs as the v(CC) band disappears at 80 °C. The very fast disappearance of the v(CO) band at 1676 and 1684 cm−1 with increasing temperature indicates that 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN is more active than the 3Mo-3Ir/BN. Therefore, the in situ FTIR results on the three catalysts are in good agreement with the observed overall catalytic behaviors of the catalysts (Fig. 6), that is, all catalysts show high selectivity and the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN possesses the highest activity while the 3Ir/BN and 3Mo-3Ir/BN are less active. 3.4 Kinetic investigation Although the FTIR results in gas phase offered useful information on the reaction behaviors of the catalysts, there might be deviation because the reaction was conducted in liquid phase. Therefore, kinetic experiments were conducted on the 3Ir/BN and 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalysts to explore their intrinsic behaviors in liquid phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde. As shown in Table S2, the reaction rate increases with increasing partial pressure of H2, while it decreases with increasing concentration of crotonaldehyde. Reaction orders of H2 and crotonaldehyde and apparent reaction constant were evaluated by plotting logarithm of reaction rate versus logarithm of the partial pressure of hydrogen and the content of crotonaldehyde (Fig. 8 ). For the formation of crotyl alcohol, the power law rate expression is r = 3.26 × 10−6 [CRAL]-1.1 [H2]2.2 (CRAL : crotonaldehyde) on the 3Ir/BN catalyst; while it is r = 5.12 × 10-6 [CRAL]-0.6 [H2]1.4 on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalyst. The 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalyst has a higher apparent rate constant than the 3Ir/BN, suggesting that it is intrinsically more active, which is in line with the overall catalytic performance as shown in Fig. 6. Moreover, the negative reaction orders of crotonaldehyde on both catalysts suggest that the presence of crotonaldehyde prohibits the reaction rate. In contrast, the reaction orders of H2 on both catalysts are very high (1.4–2.2), which can not be explained the dissociative adsorption of H2 because otherwise the reaction order of H2 would not exceed 0.5. The kinetic investigations of gas phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde over Ir catalysts [44] revealed that high reaction order of H2 (e.g. 0.6 - 0.9) is related to heterolytical dissociation of H2 on the metal surface (H2 → H+ + H-). However, it should be noted that in liquid phase reaction, the solubility of H2 in the solvent is crucial to affect the observed kinetics. Indeed, our results are similar to those obtained on Au/Mg2AlO catalysts reported by Chen et al. [33] in which a negative reaction order of crotonaldehyde (-0.55) and a positive reaction order of H2 (1.84) were reported. The authors attributed the high reaction order of H2 to its low solubility in polar solvent (e.g. isopropanol). In contrast, the crotonaldehyde molecules could be easily dissolved in the solvent, and thus readily adsorb on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the high surface coverage of crotonaldehyde hinders the surface adsorption of H2, which results in negative reaction order of crotonaldehyde. Tamura et al. [27] also reported liquid phase hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde over an Ir-ReOx/SiO2 catalyst and found a zero order of crotonaldehyde and 0.9 order of H2 indicating saturated coverage of crotonaldehyde on the catalyst surface and difficult adsorption of H2. This scenario in liquid phase is different from the observations in gas phase. For example, the kinetic study on Ir/BN and Ir-FeOx/BN catalysts for gas phase hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde reveals crotonaldehyde reaction orders of 0.1 - 0.4 [12], due to the competitive adsorption of gas phase crotonaldehyde and H2 on the catalyst surface. In addition, comparison of the rate expressions of the 3Ir/BN and 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalysts leads to some remarks. Regarding the reaction order of crotonaldehyde, the 3Ir/BN gives a more negative value (-1.1) than the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN (-0.6), implying that the prohibiting effect of crotonaldehyde on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN is somehow alleviated compared to that on the 3Ir/BN. Meanwhile, the reaction order of H2 on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN (1.4) is significantly lower than that on the 3Ir/BN (2.2), indicating that the reaction is less dependent on the partial pressure of H2 on the former (or relatively easier adsorption of H2 on the catalyst surface). This is coincident with weakened prohibiting effect of crotonaldehyde on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN, suggesting that the adsorption geometry of crotonaldehyde on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN is rather different to that on the 3Ir/BN. Indeed, the adsorption behaviors of crotonaldehyde on supported noble metal catalysts have been extensively investigated [25,28]. On bare metal (such as Pt and Ir), the adsorption of crotonaldehyde and H2 take place on the metal surface, and thus may result in a competition. However, when metal is supported on reducible oxides (such as TiO2 and Co3O4) or is promoted with other components (such as FeOx, MoOx), the adsorption of crotonaldehyde tends to occur at the metal-support or metal-promoter interface while the adsorption of H2 occurs on the metal surface, therefore, the adsorption of the two species are non-competitive [10]. Such changes in the adsorption patterns may explain the different behaviors of the 3Ir/BN and 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN catalysts, that is, the Ir-MoOx interface provides new sites for crotonaldehyde adsorption, thus alleviates the competition adsorption of H2 and relatively lower reaction order of H2. The generation of such Ir-MoOx interfacial sites also implies that reaction pathway may be altered, which is justified by the comparison of the activation energies (Eas) of the two catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8c, the Ea on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN (18.9 ± 4.3 kJ mol-1) is only half of that on the 3Ir/BN (38.4 ± 2.2 kJ mol-1), strongly suggesting a more facile reaction route on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN. Based on the above findings, the reaction behaviors of the catalysts in the liquid phase are illustrated in Fig. 9 . First of all, we would like to explicate the roles of catalyst components in the reaction. Since CRAL can adsorb on the BN support (Fig. S1), the BN may participate in the reaction because hydrogen species dissociated on metallic Ir species could migrate and react with adjacent CRAL molecules adsorbed on BN. Although the roles of BN could not be ignored, its contribution in the reaction is quite limited because otherwise the reaction behaviors of 3Ir/BN and the MoOx-containing catalysts (e.g. 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN) should not have differed so much as they have similar CRAL adsorption capacity (Fig. S1). Therefore, we believe that the reaction mainly take place on the Ir species. Accordingly, the metallic Ir species are responsible for the adsorption/activation/dissociation of H2 molecules while the cationic Ir species are responsible for the adsorption/activation of CRAL molecules (particularly the CO bond) [12]. When the Ir catalysts were promoted by FeOx, NbOx and ReOx, the promoters act as additional adsorption/activation sites for the CO bond [12,27,44], which leads to much higher activity for the reaction. Secondly, we would like to highlight the different reaction behaviors of the catalysts in the liquid phase. In our previous work, we have investigated gas phase selective hydrogenation over FeOx-promoted Ir/BN catalysts [12]. The presence of Ir-FeOx interface improves the catalytic performance, which highlights the critical role of Ir-promoter interface in the reaction. However, different behaviors in gas phase and liquid phase should be noted. Unlike in the gas phase reaction, the rate of liquid phase reaction is controlled by the H2 solubility in the solvent, while the adsorption of crotonaldehyde on the catalyst surface readily takes place. On the bare 3Ir/BN catalyst, adsorption of crotonaldehyde with CO bonds results in high selectivity, but its high coverage also hinders the adsorption/dissociation of H2 on the Ir surface and thus low activity. On the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN, the crotonaldehyde may preferably adsorb on the Ir-MoOx interfacial sites, and thus easy adsorption/dissociation of H2 on the Ir surface, which accounts for the much improved activity and selectivity. However, it should be noted that at high content of MoOx (e.g. 3Mo-3Ir/BN) such promotion may lead to less exposed Ir atoms due to excessive coverage of Ir by MoOx species, which makes H2 adsorption/activation difficult and thus leads to lowered activity compared to that on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN. Generally, previous works on Ir-MOx systems [12,18,19,27,29,36,44] for selective hydrogenation of CRAL mainly focus on the adsorption/activation of CRAL on the Ir-MOx interface, which is indeed critical in the reaction process. However, less attention has been paid on the activation of H2. In the current work, it is found that H2 adsorption/activation could also be affected by the Ir-MOx interface, which thus provides some new information on the better understanding of the reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, MoOx - promotion could greatly improve the performance of Ir/BN catalysts for liquid phase hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde due to the formation of Ir-MoOx interface, on which the adsorption/activation of crotonaldehyde is facilitated. The kinetic results suggest that the reaction rate is highly dependent on the partial pressure of H2 due to its low solubility in the solvent, thus the adsorption/activation of H2 on the surface Ir atoms may be the rate - determining step of the reaction. On the contrary, high surface coverage of crotonaldehyde prohibits the adsorption of H2 and thus results in a negative reaction order of crotonaldehyde. However, the crotonaldehyde molecules preferably adsorbed at the Ir-MoOx interface makes the H2 adsorption easier, which accounts for the higher activity. These findings in liquid phase reaction again highlight the roles of metal-promoter interface in selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde, but also reflect different features compared to the behaviors in gas phase reaction. In liquid phase reaction, the adsorption and activation of H2 becomes the limiting step because of its low solubility in solvent and high surface coverage of crotonaldehyde on the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A series of MoOx-promoted Ir/BN catalysts were tested for liquid phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde. The MoOx-promotion could significantly improve the reactivity up to 5-fold. Such improvement was mainly due to the formation of Ir-MoOx interfacial sites in the promoted catalyst, which accelerated the adsorption and activation of crotonaldehyde molecule as evidenced by a much lower activation energy (18.9 kJ mol−1 on the 0.3Mo-3Ir/BN versus 38.4 kJ mol−1 on the 3Ir/BN). The kinetic results revealed negative reaction order of crotonaldehyde (up to -1.1) and high reaction order of H2 (up to 2.2), indicating the high coverage of crotonaldehyde on the catalyst surface suppressed the adsorption of H2 due to its low solubility in the liquid phase. Therefore, the adsorption and activation of H2 on the catalyst might be the rate determining step. However, the preferred adsorption of crotonaldehyde on the Ir-MoOx interface alleviated the suppression of H2 adsorption, which was another reason for the higher activity.
coredata.dc:title: The roles of metal-promoter interface on liquid phase selective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde over Ir-MoOx/BN catalysts
